awd_titl_txt: Wyoming King Air as a National Facility
awd_abstract_narration:
The University of Wyoming will continue providing the King Air aircraft (UWKA), Wyoming Cloud Radar (WCR) and Wyoming Cloud Lidar (WCL) as part of the national Lower Atmosphere Observing Facility (LAOF) suite. The UWKA is a twin turbo-prop aircraft highly instrumented for measurements throughout the atmosphere up to altitudes of 10 km (33,000 ft). WCR and WCL are sophisticated remote-sensing instruments that provide observations of the three-dimensional structure of clouds and their evolution over time. This cooperative agreement provides base support to a staff of scientists, engineers, technicians, pilots and mechanics who operate, maintain and improve the aircraft, cloud radar and cloud lidar facilities. During this performance period (2014-2018), the University of Wyoming will deploy the King Air aircraft and WCR and WCL instruments in support of research projects deemed to be of exceptional merit by the peer review process. Staff will also upgrade the aircraft and available instrumentation to facilitate cutting edge research in the areas of atmospheric dynamics, atmospheric chemistry, and cloud physics.

Intellectual Merit: The University of Wyoming King Air fulfills a unique role in the suite of NSF-supported lower atmosphere observing facilities, serving as the only small, light aircraft available to atmospheric researchers. UWKA carries a state-of-the-art complement of instrumentation for measuring the physical and chemical properties of the atmosphere, for understanding the formation and evolution of clouds and their interaction with atmospheric aerosols, and for investigating the dynamical mechanisms that cause and maintain severe weather, especially winter storms and heavy precipitation. Planned development and acquisition of new instrumentation will facilitate research by the atmospheric sciences community as it tackles questions related to weather and climate.

Broader impacts: As an advanced-degree-granting institution, the University of Wyoming and its UWKA facility provide unique opportunities for both undergraduate and graduate students to learn about and obtain hands-on experience with nearly every aspect of observational atmospheric science. These opportunities are open to students from UW and other academic institutions, as well as to high school students taking a summer course on aviation weather. Most deployments of the UWKA include educational programs for or outreach to local communities, media, and schools, which exposes the general public to this unique application of science, technology and engineering expertise.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this cooperative agreement (CA) between the University of Wyoming (UWyo) and the National Science Foundation was to provide the UWyo King Air Research Aircraft (UWKA) as a multi-user national facility for use by the geosciences community under the NSF Lower Atmosphere Observing Facility (LAOF) Program, including the Wyoming Cloud Radar (WCR, added to CA5 in 2004), and the Wyoming Cloud Lidar (WCL, added in 2010). This was the seventh NSF/UWyo cooperative agreement (CA7) in the sequence beginning in 1987, funding deployments of these systems during the period 6/1/2014-5/31/2019. No-cost extensions of CA7 were approved through 31 December 2021 so that unexpended funds could be utilized.

Summary of NSF science projects supported:

During the first 5 years of this CA, we flew the UWKA 719 hours of which 78% were directly in support of fourteen NSF project deployments, averaging 113 hours per year.  With the two additional deployments of the WCR and WCL installed on the NSF/NCAR C-130, we averaged a total of about 2 deployments per year during this period.  The projects supported are summarized in the attached table.

Broader impacts and Intellectual Merit:

The Department of Atmospheric Science at UWyo has an advanced degree-granting program, affording students a unique opportunity to learn about the principles of observational atmospheric research on an airplane, both in the classroom and also obtaining hands-on experience with measurements and also scientific flight planning, flight direction, and data collection.

The Department also has developed a strong engineering support group that works closely with both the faculty and also with the principal investigators who request and work with the airplane while deployed. UWyo faculty and staff have instrumented and operated research aircraft for their research since the 1960s, providing a rich experiential base for configuring the aircraft with capabilities relevant to current scientific and societal needs. This has motivated advancements in measurement and data collection systems on the UWKA ? notably the in situ cloud sensor suite, and most recently the multi-beam 95 GHz cloud radar (WCR), and the upward and downward pointing lidars (WCLs)?with funding from an array of sources, including NSF, NASA, DoD, and the University itself. These advancements have provided the geosciences community at large with an up-to-date and very capable research facility.

  • The projects supported during CA7 allowed the involvement of undergraduate and graduate students in flight operations, both for students from the University of Wyoming students and other universities. In particular, both SEAR-MAR and TECPEC, funded from the NSF/LAOF Deployment Pool as an Educational Project, were specifically designed to allow students to be involved directly in-flight planning and research operations. These projects involved students from the University of Wyoming, the University of Utah, Millersville University, Pennsylvania State University, Rutgers, and the University of Maryland, Baltimore County. During the last 3 educational flights at Broomfield, CO, the graduate students from the University of Wyoming, Colorado State, and the University of Montana have successfully operated the WCL after a WCL operator training.
  • We have identified 251 refereed scientific journal articles published during the period 2004 to the present involving data collected by the UWKA, WCR, and WCL. This is probably an underestimate of the actual number of publications resulting from these deployments.
  • Numerous outreach events took place throughout CA7, targeting student groups as well as the general public. The SEAR-MAR project included open house displays for the UWKA, focused in particular on students from Millersville University and a middle school STEM sisters group affiliated with the Lancaster North Museum of Nature and Science. The TECPEC project included an open house display for the UWKA, open to students from the University of Utah as well as the general public.
  • The UWKA took part in an open house display at the 2017 Cheyenne Frontier Days celebration, with tours and presentations given to the general public.
  • The presence and accessibility of the UWKA, WCR, and WCL provided unique opportunities undergraduate research, and for advanced degree study in the UWyo Department of Atmospheric Science. During CA7 (2014 ? 2021) and other universities involved in supported NSF projects. Twenty-eight advanced MS and PhD degrees related to observational atmospheric research have been granted in the period 2014-2021. A more complete list can be seen at https://www.uwyo.edu/atsc/uwka/theses-dissertations.html.
  • We have identified about 250 refereed scientific journal articles published from data collected by the UWKA, WCR, and WCL. This is probably an underestimate of the actual number of publications resulting from these deployments. A full list is available at https://www.uwyo.edu/atsc/uwka/publications.html.
